Paramedics joined drivers to drag Insulate Britain demonstrators off a busy road yesterday as the group defied government attempts to stop the protests.
A furious woman berated protesters blocking the Blackwall Tunnel in London after telling them that she was trying to visit her mother in hospital in Canterbury. She wept as she asked them, “How can you be so selfish?”.
Insulate Britain caused hours of disruption when they blocked roads yesterday morning at Wandsworth Bridge, Hanger Lane and Arnos Grove in the capital. By midday police had arrested 38 of the 54 protesters from the Extinction Rebellion splinter group who took part.
The Metropolitan Police said that all roads were clear at 12.20pm.

https://www.thetimes.com/business-money/.title: Inside the Amazon tribe fighting deforestation: âThis is warâ
https://www.thetimes.com/business-money/.text:
The children tumble from the trees into the igarapÃ©, or forest brook, sending up beads of water. Fingers of sunlight break through the patchwork-green canopy overhead, illuminating them. A cobalt-winged butterfly flits past, mesmerising in its brilliance.
Drying off quickly in the hot Amazon sun, the youngsters scramble up a muddy path to their village of SawrÃ© Muybu, home to about 130 indigenous Munduruku people â one in a chain of Munduruku settlements that stretch along the Tapajos River in the northern Brazilian state of Para. One small girl wears a silvery marmoset on her head as if it were a hat. A boy clutches a pet coati with a long striped tail.
Under a thatched shelter behind the chiefâs house, their parents sit around a communal cooking fire. Many have fish-scale or tortoiseshell designs inked across their faces, arms and legs. A bright-green parakeet darts from shoulder to shoulder and a pet monkey chatters under a table. A few hunters with knives and bows wander in, bearing a wild boar that will be skinned, cooked and shared, eaten with yams grown in their small plantations. There are a few incongruous signs of modernity â a fridge, a satellite dish, mobile phones, a generator and a sit-on toilet â but in other ways life for these people, existing side by side with nature, has barely changed for centuries.
Any sense of an idyll, however, is shattered by a droning, throbbing hum â the unmistakable sound of a large motor. Immediately in front of the village on the river is a monstrous dredging platform, two storeys high, cobbled together Heath Robinson-style from scrap metal and parts including the landing gear of an Airbus.
Inside, four men are sifting through silt pumped up from the riverbed, which cascades down wooden ramps. They are garimpeiros â gold prospectors â looking for nuggets. The residue is made into what look like black doormats that will be taken along the river to the nearby town of Itaituba to process. The men, all from the northeast of Brazil, the poorest part of the country, dredge from dawn to dusk, for 12-14 hours, and on a good day will retrieve 20g of gold: âDa para sobreviver,â they tell me â âEnough to live on.â
The Munduruku, who number about 14,000, have the misfortune to live in the most gold-rich region in Brazil and though mining for gold in indigenous lands is illegal, the Brazilian government has no intention, it seems, to enforce the law â indeed, it is trying to change it.
âThese gold-dredgers are not new. Whatâs new is how brazen it is â itâs a free-for-all. Before, they used to hide up channels,â says Mauricio Torres, a professor at the Federal University of Para who has been travelling in the area for 20 years, studying conflicts on indigenous lands. âThe real villains are not these men but the owners outside,â he adds. âDredges like these cost a million reals [Â£135,000] and are run by organised groups.â
The damage is clear to see. The dredging has turned the river, which the Munduruku consider sacred, from pale blue to muddy brown. Large sandbanks have piled up in front of the village jetty. The mercury the dredgers use to separate the gold from the sandy soil pollutes the river and contaminates their fish.
Last year a child died of mercury poisoning. Mercury has also been linked to birth defects and neurological disorders. A recent study by Brazilâs Fiocruz health institute in partnership with the World Wildlife Fund found that 58 per cent of Munduruku tested in the Tapajos River region had levels of mercury higher than that considered safe.
Thatâs not all the Munduruku have to contend with. To get to SawrÃ© Muybu involved me taking two flights from Rio, an eight-hour boat trip along the Tapajos, a two-hour car journey, then two hours in a canoe. But being remote has not protected them. Illegal loggers have invaded the area. Then there is what is known locally as grilagem â land-grabbing to grow soya or rear beef cattle for the global food industry.
Brazil is the worldâs biggest meat exporter. In 2016 the Munduruku narrowly avoided having their lands flooded when government plans to build a vast hydroelectric dam across the Tapajos were halted by protests. Now the government wants to construct a ferrogrÃ£o â grain railway â to transport soya to the huge port in Itaituba, from where it is exported to China and Europe.
The fate of the planetâs largest rainforest will be high on the agenda when world leaders gather in Glasgow today for the Cop26 climate change conference, which the host, Boris Johnson, has insisted must be a âturning point for humanityâ. For those on the ground in the Amazon, the turning point has arrived.
âWe are in a state of war,â says Cacique Juarez Saw Munduruku, 61, the village chief, his lined face furrowing. This is nothing new for the Munduruku, a warrior clan who over the centuries have fought off rival tribes and Portuguese colonialists alike, and are known as âfire antsâ because of their mass assaults. Their word for stranger â pariwati â also means enemy and they once had a reputation for placing the severed heads of their adversaries on spikes.
Today their main enemy is the Brazilian government. Since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s, no regime has been as openly hostile towards the Munduruku and other indigenous groups as that of President Jair Bolsonaro. A former army captain, he has long contested the amount of land reserved as tribal territory. As a congressman in the late 1990s, he raged: âItâs a shame the Brazilian cavalry wasnât as efficient as the Americans, who exterminated the Indians.â
During his presidential campaign in 2018, many of Bolsonaroâs backers were in agribusiness. He vowed that once elected, he would not designate âa single centimetre moreâ of land as indigenous territory, insisting the tribes had too much already.
Although the countryâs constitution of 1988 guaranteed land to all Brazilâs 305 tribes and stated that indigenous territories should have all been demarcated by now, Bolsonaroâs administration has halted the process, leaving a third of indigenous land yet to be demarcated and 237 requests pending â including that of SawrÃ© Muybu.
He has also reduced Brazilâs capacity to protect existing reserves by slashing funding to the countryâs environmental agency, Ibama, and sacking thousands of government functionaries charged with monitoring them. This has emboldened those intent on plundering the forest, pushing deforestation to its highest level for 13 years, and has left indigenous communities even more vulnerable to encroachments and violent attacks.
The Sunday Times Magazine first alerted the world to the plight of the indigenous people living in the Amazon in 1969, in a cover story by the writer Norman Lewis headlined âGenocideâ. That led to an international outcry and campaign. Fiona Watson, director of advocacy for Survival International, an organisation created in response to Lewisâs article to give indigenous peoples a voice on the world stage, says the situation is desperate.
âPresident Bolsonaro has launched the biggest assault on indigenous peoples since the military dictatorship,â she says. âThe situation is without doubt the worst Iâve seen in 35 years working in Brazil and certainly the most dangerous time in decades to be indigenous, as violence against their communities is escalating and the destruction of their Amazon homeland has reached catastrophic proportions.â
Last year was the most violent to date, with a record 1,576 land disputes, according to Brazilâs Pastoral Land Commission, a church organisation that has been tracking land invasions since 1985. Almost half were against indigenous people. Few aggressors are ever brought to justice, and nowhere are there more attacks than in the state of Para.
Garimpeiros have turned particularly aggressive. In May this year, gold prospectors invaded a village in the Munduruku reserve, firing guns and setting houses on fire. One of the houses burnt to the ground belonged to the village chief and another was the home of Maria Leusa Munduruku, an indigenous leader and co-ordinator of the local womenâs movement. âPlease come, itâs chaos, theyâre going to burn my house â¦ They are shooting, please help me!â she cried in an audio message sent to APIB, Brazilâs largest indigenous organisation, just before communication with the village was cut off.
âThey arrived with petrol in soft-drink bottles, armed and shooting,â she said afterwards. âWe received phone messages saying we had to be killed because we were getting in the way, that we were denouncing their activities.â
Many of the Munduruku now leading the battle against the invaders are women. On my third morning staying with the community, sleeping in a hammock in their school room, I hear a commotion. âThe warriors are back!â The shout resounds through the village, sending parrots and chickens squawking and children with painted faces scurrying.
Juarez Saw Munduruku, the village chief, and a small band of men, women and teenage boys with hair dyed green or purple, have spent the past four days armed with GPS devices as well as bows and arrows and machetes, hacking their way through dense jungle to hammer wooden signs printed with the words Terra Protegida (Protected Land) onto tree trunks on the edges of their territory.
The signs look official but are in fact copies. Though their land was mapped by Ibama in 2014 the authorities have never officially declared it a reserve, so the Munduruku have been forced into what they call self-demarcation â installing signs around the edge of all 434,900 acres of their ancestral land, as a warning to those who would plunder its riches.
Lagging behind in flip-flops, exhausted after the long hike, battling with humidity as well as the threat of venomous snakes, scorpions, spiders, even jaguars, walks a pint-sized woman dressed in a grass skirt with a headband of orange and black feathers over her long black hair. âThe world talks about environment but weâre the ones whose feet are cut to pieces,â says Alessandra Korap Munduruku, 37, a mother of two boys and the tribeâs campaign co-ordinator, who tells me she will be travelling to Glasgow to alert the world to their plight. After a refreshing dip in the brook, she sits by a mango tree from which a monkey swings on a rope and explains how she became the Mundurukuâs first female warrior.
âI got involved in 2015 when I attended a course on the rights of indigenous people,â she says. âIâd never thought how, when they stopped us fishing by polluting our water, they were actually taking our rights. So I joined the fight with the cacique [chief] â only I couldnât because I am a woman and women have to stay quiet. In our society, women are married off at 12 or 13. I was lucky, as I didnât marry till 21. My own mother said, âAlessandra, you canât speak, let the cacique speak.â I said, âWhy not?â I had always been a rebel and questioned everything, was always in fights. So I began to speak at meetings. To start with people were shocked but now they say, âLetâs wait for Alessandra to see what she thinks.â â
She started accompanying Cacique Juarez to Brasilia, the capital, for meetings, but soon branched out on her own. Last month she addressed the senate to warn of the impact of the proposed railway.
âI discovered many things from dealing with whites,â she says. âIf they give, they always want something in return.â
She began studying law at the Federal University of Western Para after learning that two places were being offered for indigenous students. More than 500 applied but she was chosen. She has struggled to keep up with the course alongside her work organising resistance. âItâs a challenge to be a woman, to be in the struggle, to be a mum, to be a warrior â it feels as if I have the world on my shoulders,â she says.
Like Maria Leusa, she risks her life for her cause. âI am threatened like mad but I refuse to stay quiet,â she shrugs. âThis is war and we must prepare for it.â In 2019, when she travelled to Brasilia with other indigenous leaders, her house was broken into and her bag and documents stolen. âAfterwards my son hugged me and said, âMum, I donât want them to kill you.â â
Since then she rarely stays in one place. âWhy should I feel fear? The people who should feel fear are those who are doing wrong. The greatest fear I have is my people being expelled from their territory.â
Yet the war people like Alessandra are fighting is for the whole of humanity. The Amazon not only contains 10 per cent of the planetâs biodiversity but plays a vital role in mitigating climate change by acting as a sink, absorbing and storing carbon dioxide, and is often referred to as the lungs of the world. When cut or burnt down, the forest not only ceases to fulfil this function but also releases the stored carbon back into the atmosphere.
Under Bolsonaro deforestation has continued relentlessly. Between August last year and this July, 10,476 sq km of forest was wiped out â an area nearly seven times bigger than Greater London, according to data released by Imazon, a Brazilian research institute that has been tracking Amazon deforestation since 2007.
So much so that for the first time, parts of the forest are emitting more CO2 than they absorb. Scientists are warning that as much as 40 per cent of the Amazon has been so devastated that it is reaching a point of no return, at which it could switch from a rainforest to a savanna, which would have profound effects on the global climate.
âWe are headed for a catastrophic temperature rise of 3-5C this century,â warned Antonio Guterres, secretary-general of the UN. âMaking peace with nature is the defining task of the 21st century. It must be the top priority for everyone, everywhere.â
Bolsonaro insists he agrees. âWhich other country in the world has a policy of environmental protection like ours?â he asked in his speech at the UN general assembly last month. In a way he is correct: other countries have long ago cut down their forests, whereas international alarm at the terrifying rate of Amazonian deforestation in the 1980s led Brazil to enact conservation measures and the rate slowed. But now Bolsonaroâs administration has been trying to roll back these measures. He claimed that deforestation was down in August, but shocking photos released by Greenpeace suggested otherwise.
Bolsonaroâs environment minister, Ricardo Salles, was forced to resign in June after the Brazilian supreme court announced an investigation into allegations that he and top officials in his ministry helped companies traffic illegally logged rainforest wood to Europe and the United States.
That followed the largest seizure of illegal timber in Brazilâs history â eight million cubic feet of wood â on the border between Para and Amazonas states, which police claimed they had been instructed to release.
âNo one protects the forest better than indigenous people,â says Professor Torres at the University of Para. âMunduruku are the front line of resistance â particularly the women. They are preserving the forest for themselves and their children, but it has an impact for the whole world.â
Earlier this year Alessandraâs bravery was recognised with the Robert Kennedy Human Rights Award. âI never imagined Iâd get a prize in my life,â she laughs. âMy relatives always complained I was a troublemaker. But now theyâre proud and want their daughters to be like us. In the past I walked alone, it was just me and Maria Leusa. Today there are a band of girls.â
Not only are women at the forefront but they are employing very different means from warriors of the past. Among them is Beka Munduruku, just turned 18, often referred to as the Greta of the Amazon, who posts photos on Instagram of herself and her jungle habitat. âMy life used to be just playing but then I saw how they were destroying our river and home,â she says. âMy people need to get our story out. Now we use WhatsApp, Facebook and Insta as weapons.â
Beka is part of a high-tech all-female team headed by Aldira, a former village teacher. While her husband looks after their four children, including a three-month-old baby, Aldira travels around with a drone, mapping deforestation and land invasions, then sends her videos to the authorities.
âThey donât do anything, but at least we register it,â she says. I watch her launch the drone over an area stripped of trees, dressed in a grass skirt and feathers, arms and legs decorated with black war paint. âIf we donât fight for the forest, who will?â she adds. âThe forest gives us life and has life like us. To us, everything in the forest and river are sacred and this banditry will have consequences.â
She tells me how the Munduruku have become fearful of eating fish, once a mainstay of their diet, owing to the fear of contamination from mercury. The problem is not just the dredger.
One morning Anderson Paygo, 32, wearing a graphic T-shirt printed with the words âF*** Youâ over his thickly muscled arms, takes us by canoe up the river to see a goldmine. The grandson of the former chief, he is co-ordinator of 11 villages on the river, representing about 1,200 people.
âWe have a lot of richness in wood, gold, even diamonds â and this government encourages people to take them,â he says.
Last year Bolsonaro introduced a draft bill in congress to allow mining and other commercial activities in indigenous territories, part of what Greenpeace has denounced as the Destruction Package. The bill is listed as one of Bolsonaroâs priorities. The National Mining Agency has received 2,899 requests to mine in indigenous territories, 1,265 in lands where there are uncontacted tribes).
Among them are 86 applications from the mining giant Anglo American, including in Munduruku land, though it is believed to have withdrawn some recently after questions were raised at a shareholdersâ meeting.âNeither Anglo American nor any of its subsidiaries hold any exploration permits on indigenous lands in Brazil,â the company says. âWe have withdrawn all applications for mineral exploration in areas located within indigenous lands, but several of these applications have not yet been removed from the database of the National Mining Agency (ANM).â
Some communities might lose their land altogether if a case known as Marco Temporal, or the âTime Limit Trickâ, is passed by the supreme court. It follows a federal regional court ruling that it would only recognise tribal lands occupied by native communities at the time Brazilâs constitution was ratified in 1988 â which saw the territory of one tribe, the Xokleng, drastically reduced on the basis they were living on only a fraction of it.
âIt feels like we are fighting grileiros [invaders] from every side,â Paygo says. âAnd if the government passes those laws it will be much worse. In the past our life here was very free, just hunting and fishing, but now we have to patrol our land and our leadership have to leave the village a lot to campaign. Itâs not just time and effort but risk â they want the heads of me and Alessandra. But we have to do it to defend the future of our families. We donât have fear for we are a warrior people and have always fought.â
Paygo points out a strange indentation in the trees like a ski slope â the Passage of the Wild Pigs â which he says is one of the tribeâs most sacred sites. According to their legend, the Munduruku were created by their god, Karosakaybu, born from the seed of a palm tree in SawrÃ© Muybu. He first created fish and the river, then pigs that came down this passage to the river.
Shortly after passing it, we come to a small beach and climb out. Three scrawny men are waiting on the bank for the fortnightly supply boat. Ze, 57, Manuel and Guido, both 56, are garimpeiros from the goldmine a few miles inland. Tracks from heavy machinery mark the way towards large craters, like scars in the forest. âSix years ago there were as many as 2,000 people here with bars, shops and women,â Ze says. âNow there are just a few. Thereâs not much gold left.â
The garimpeiros tell us they had no idea this was indigenous land. They say they havenât been home in two years and had no alternative but to find work here.
Two are divorced, one is separated and conditions in the jungle are grim, with frequent bouts of malaria. The supply boat comes and they load up with cooking oil, frozen chickens, a sack of corn, a long coil of sausage, tobacco and a couple of bottles of cachaÃ§a sugarcane spirit.
Not all garimpeiros are outsiders. Among those who attacked Maria Leusa were Munduruku who have turned their back on their ancient culture. The government has been trying to split the tribe, Paygo says. âOur God taught us to share, so when our people hunt and fish they always share everything, but itâs the strategy of this government to pit one family against another. Unfortunately some Munduruku joined our enemy and became garimpeiros. Some of our own family threaten us.â
Last year Bolsonaro posted a video on social media declaring: âThe Indian has changed, he is evolving and becoming more and more a human being like us. What we want is to integrate him into society so he can own his land.â
Alessandra and Cacique Juarez are trying to counter this by finding new sources of income. The chief has been planting coffee and cacao. Alessandra has opened a craft store in Itaituba, a steamy Wild West town full of gold shops and brothels as well as hardware stores selling tree-cutting tools. One gold shop has a âBar do Garimpeiroâ inside, offering prospectors free drinks as their nuggets are weighed by young women in tight T-shirts and men in suits.
Some 17.7 tonnes of illegal gold entered the market from the state of Para last year, according to new figures from federal prosecutors, a third of it from garimpeiros in the Munduruku and Kayapo reserves. Some of this is believed to end up in the UK, which is the third biggest buyer of Brazilian gold.
Next to a pecking macaw, a small group of surly teenage Munduruku boys with blue-dyed hair sit smoking and playing on their phones. The chief worries that young people are losing interest in their heritage. âWe chiefs are like libraries for our tribes,â he says. âIn the past we didnât have TV but they have phones and games. Our children are not interested in the old stories and are losing their language. If we lose our language and culture, what will we have? Soon the government will say these are not indigenous people, they are Brazilians like any other.â
To protect them, he is uniting with other indigenous tribes â even old enemies. âWe must come together or this government will do away with all of us,â he says. âToday weâre living through a period of legislative genocide,â says Dario Kopenawa, a leader of the Yanomami people, who have seen 20,000 garimpeiros flood into their territory. âThey are killing us with a pen.â
A few days after we leave, Alessandra herds 46 Munduruku onto a bus to Brasilia, a three-day journey, to take part in the countryâs biggest ever demonstration by indigenous people. More than 6,000 representatives of some 176 tribes pitch tents and build bamboo shelters in which they camp for a seven-day protest titled Luta pela Vida, or Struggle for Life.
They make a striking vision dressed in their brightly coloured feathers against the gleaming white space-age buildings of congress, the supreme court and the presidential palace. Among them is Beka, live streaming to her followers.
âA lot of people still think of indigenous people as they were back in 1500, like something in a museum,â she says. âWe still have our traditions but weâve learnt to use modern ways â mobile phones, social media, speaking Portuguese â and we women are feminists. It doesnât mean weâve stopped being indigenous people.â

By Ben Spencer, science editor
World leaders and environmental activists from 195 countries start gathering in Glasgow today for what is billed as the âlast, best chance to save the planetâ. The key focus is on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but the UK, as host of Cop26, is also pushing for an ambitious deal to halt and reverse global deforestation. Brazil, the worldâs largest beef exporter, is unlikely to play ball. If the deal falters, what can the rest of us do?
Much of the food we eat either comes from or is linked to cleared land that used to be South American rainforest. Efforts to clean up the food industry have been muddied by the complexity of supply chains, particularly for processed foods such as ready meals and canned meat goods. Recent Greenpeace investigations into JBS â an international meat giant whose UK customers include several supermarkets, restaurant chains and wholesalers â found that among its suppliers were ranchers linked to deforestation. JBS insists it does not tolerate any illegal deforestation in the Amazon.
But imported meat products are only part of the problem. Soya bean, a key driver of deforestation in the Amazon, is a main source of feed for British farm animals. Three quarters of the soya imported by the UK is used as animal feed. In Europe we eat twice as much meat and three times as much dairy as the global average. The Rainforest Foundation says we can make a difference by reducing our meat intake. And when we do eat meat, we should buy from local farms with sustainable practices.
Palm oil â used in food and cosmetics â is another driver of deforestation worldwide. Read the labels on products to see if they contain palm oil and whether it comes from a sustainable source.
âDecades of inaction by governments and companies have created the crisis, emboldening the Brazilian government to further exploit the Amazon by pushing through some of the most destructive legislation ever seen,â says Anna Jones, head of forests at Greenpeace UK.
âTrusted brands still buy from forest destroyers despite promises to remove deforestation from their supply chains by 2020. Immediate action is needed on all fronts. Supermarkets must immediately drop meat suppliers owned by forest destroyers and governments must close legislative loopholes to ensure deforestation-free supply chains are exactly that.â
Brazilâs illegally mined gold also finds its way to Britain. A report published last month by the Federal University of Minas Gerais found that three countries â the UK, Switzerland and Canada â buy 72 per cent of Brazilâs gold exports. âIt is very likely that those countries have imported gold linked to destructive activities in the Amazon,â the authors said. Buyers should source gold that comes from a verified low-impact mine, or buy recycled gold.
